docs.title: Deluge Community Firmware
docs.text:
Synthstrom Audible released the source code of the Deluge firmware and started a Github community project inviting everyone to participate in improving and extending the Deluge user experience.

To that end, this website was developed so that up-to-date documentation for the Deluge Community Firmware could be maintained. Everyone is welcome to participate in improving and extending this documentation.

docs.title: Contributing to the documentation
docs.text:
You're welcome to contribute to this documentation whether you're a Deluge Community Firmware contributor or an enthusiastic Deluge user.

You can contribute to the documentation by cloning this repository, making changes and rebuilding the site locally, then submitting your changes back to the repository as a pull request (PR).

docs.title: Setting up a development environment
docs.text:
1. Install Git.

  2. Install Python, Pip, and MKDocs by following the instructions at https://www.mkdocs.org/user-guide/installation/.

  3. Install Material for MkDocs by following the instructions at https://squidfunk.github.io/mkdocs-material/getting-started/.

  4. (Optional) Install VS Code to use as a code editor and help you manage your Git files.

    • For an introduction, see Using Git source control in VS Code.

docs.title: Previewing your changes
docs.text:
• To turn on a local web server that refreshes each time you save changes, enter the following in the termal:
mkdocs serve

docs.title: Submitting your changes
docs.text:
Before submitting any changes to the repo, you must use MKDocs to build the site with your latest changes.

  • Build the site by entering the following in the terminal:
mkdocs build

docs.title: Documentation style guide
docs.text:
To make the documentation consistent and accessible, you should try to align your content with the following style standards.

Best effort is much more important than perfection. Follow the style guide as best you can and allow others to edit your content to bring it in line with the style standards.

docs.title: Screen elements and physical buttons
docs.text:
• When naming screen elements and physical buttons, use **bold**. For example:
  • To enable Sticky Shift, tap Shift.
  • Go to Settings > MIDI, and enable MIDI-THRU.

docs.title: Control combinations
docs.text: • Use + for control combinations. For example, "To create a new kit, press Shift+Kit".

docs.title: File naming conventions
docs.text: Use lowercase, hyphenated names for all Markdown files (e.g., getting-started.md, api-reference.md). Names should be descriptive and concise.

docs.title: Page structure
docs.text:
Pages should follow this structure:

# Topic name

Author: Your Name (Optional)

1-2 paragraph introduction for context.

## Section

### Sub-section

docs.title: Headings
docs.text:
• Start each document with a H1 title (# Title).
  • Use H2 (##) for primary sections, H3 (###) for subsections, and so on.
  • Avoid skipping header levels.
  • Include a blank line under headings for readability in the source Markdown.
  • Use sentence case (that is, capitalize only the first letter) for headings, such as ## Installation guide.

docs.title: Writing Style
docs.text:
These style guidelines help make the documentation accessible to people from various language backgrounds and abilities.

  • Tone: Use a clear, friendly, and professional tone.
  • Voice: Prefer the active voice (e.g., “Install the package” rather than “The package is installed”).
  • Pronouns: Address the reader as “you” when giving instructions.
  • Tense: Use present tense where possible (e.g., “This command installs…”).
  • Clarity: Aim for concise, plain language. Avoid jargon, idioms, and complex sentences.

docs.title: Lists
docs.text:
• Bulleted Lists: Use for lists where the order doesn't matter. For consistency, use - instead of *.
  • Numbered Lists: Use for lists where the ordered matters. If there is only one ordered step in a section, use -.
  • Keep list items parallel in structure (e.g., start each item with a verb or noun for consistency).

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Use descriptive text for links.
    • Prefer: "For more information, see the GitHub Markdown Guide"
    • Avoid: "For more information, click here"
  • Use inline links where possible, but reference links are okay if they improve readability.

docs.title: Images
docs.text: Place images in a designated assets or images folder and link relative paths, such as ![Diagram](assets/diagram.png). Add descriptive alt text for accessibility. Use PNG for diagrams and SVG for vector images when possible.

docs.title: Tables
docs.text: Use tables sparingly and only for structured data that’s difficult to read in list format. Keep tables simple, avoiding excessive width.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
• Use "such as" or "for example" (instead of "e.g.")
    • Prefer: "For more information, see the GitHub Markdown Guide"
    • Avoid: "For more information, click here"
  • Use "that is" instead of "i.e."
  • Use "and similar" instead of "etc."
